item.title: Sarah add a quote by Marion Zimmer Bradley
item.description: "The road that is built in hope is more pleasant to the traveler than the road built in despair, even though they both lead to the same destination." -- Marion Zimmer Bradley

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Alan Bennett
item.description: "What she was finding also was how one book led to another, doors kept opening wherever she turned and the days weren't long enough for the reading she wanted to do." -- Alan Bennett

item.title: Sarah add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "Poets have been mysteriously silent on the subject of cheese." -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Isadora Duncan
item.description: "You were once wild here. Don’t let them tame you." -- Isadora Duncan

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Honoré de Balzac
item.description: "The more one judges, the less one loves." -- Honoré de Balzac

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Ralph Waldo Emerson
item.description: "It is one of the blessings of old friends that you can afford to be stupid with them." -- Ralph Waldo Emerson

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Joseph Brodsky
item.description: "There are worse crimes than burning books. One of them is not reading them." -- Joseph Brodsky

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Amy Sedaris
item.description: "I think it's good for a person to spend time alone. It gives them an opportunity to discover who they are and to figure out why they are always alone." -- Amy Sedaris

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Alexander Pope
item.description: "To err is human, to forgive, divine." -- Alexander Pope

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "In the spring, at the end of the day, you should smell like dirt." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Nora Ephron
item.description: "Above all, be the heroine of your life, not the victim." -- Nora Ephron

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Tina Fey
item.description: "Some people say, “Never let them see you cry.” I say, if you’re so mad you could just cry, then cry. It terrifies everyone." -- Tina Fey

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Peter Shaffer
item.description: "The trouble is if you don’t spend your life yourself, other people spend it for you." -- Peter Shaffer

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Stanley Kunitz
item.description: "The universe is a continuous web. Touch it at any point and the whole web quivers." -- Stanley Kunitz

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Washington Irving
item.description: "A mother is the truest friend we have, when trials heavy and sudden fall upon us; when adversity takes the place of prosperity; when friends desert us; when trouble thickens around us, still will she cling to us, and endeavor by her kind precepts and counsels to dissipate the clouds of darkness, and cause peace to return to our hearts." -- Washington Irving

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Ambrose Bierce
item.description: "Love, n. A temporary insanity curable by marriage." -- Ambrose Bierce

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Katherine Anne Porter
item.description: "The past is never where you think you left it." -- Katherine Anne Porter

item.title: Sarah add a quote by J.M. Barrie
item.description: "I'm not young enough to know everything." -- J.M. Barrie

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Robert Browning
item.description: "Who hears music, feels his solitude Peopled at once." -- Robert Browning

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Christopher Morley
item.description: "There is no mistaking a real book when one meets it. It is like falling in love." -- Christopher Morley

item.title: Sarah add a quote by John Ford
item.description: "Revenge proves its own executioner." -- John Ford

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Dodie Smith
item.description: "Noble deeds and hot baths are the best cures for depression." -- Dodie Smith

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Joseph Heller
item.description: "Some men are born mediocre, some men achieve mediocrity, and some men have mediocrity thrust upon them." -- Joseph Heller

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Charles M. Schulz
item.description: "Nothing takes the taste out of peanut butter quite like unrequited love." -- Charles M. Schulz

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Tom Wolfe
item.description: "One belongs to New York instantly, one belongs to it as much in five minutes as in five years." -- Tom Wolfe

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Yet it would be your duty to bear it, if you could not avoid it: it is weak and silly to say you cannot bear what it is your fate to be required to bear." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Sarah add a quote by Brent weeks
item.description: "The truth is, everyone likes to look down on someone. If your favorites are all avant-garde writers who throw in Sanskrit and German, you can look down on everyone. If your favorites are all Oprah Book Club books, you can at least look down on mystery readers. Mystery readers have sci-fi readers. Sci-fi can look down on fantasy. And yes, fantasy readers have their own snobbishness. I’ll bet this, though: in a hundred years, people will be writing a lot more dissertations on Harry Potter than on John Updike. Look, Charles Dickens wrote popular fiction. Shakespeare wrote popular fiction—until he wrote his sonnets, desperate to show the literati of his day that he was real artist. Edgar Allan Poe tied himself in knots because no one realized he was a genius. The core of the problem is how we want to define “literature”. The Latin root simply means “letters”. Those letters are either delivered—they connect with an audience—or they don’t. For some, that audience is a few thousand college professors and some critics. For others, its twenty million women desperate for romance in their lives. Those connections happen because the books successfully communicate something real about the human experience. Sure, there are trashy books that do really well, but that’s because there are trashy facets of humanity. What people value in their books—and thus what they count as literature—really tells you more about them than it does about the book." -- Brent weeks
